You're overwhelmed by the feeling that you've seen this tale of corporate greed and arrogant mismanagement before. Still, the filmmakers tell it with gusto.
If the religious discussions in David Magee's script occasionally seem contrived, they're also quite sincere.
As a documentary about East-West tensions and freedom of speech during the Arab Spring, it's frequently fascinating.
As the title suggests, it's all in the details, which writer-director Estes provides in large if not always convincing doses.
More than any previous non-documentary Holocaust movie, this one convinces through the accumulation of such detail.
Filled with characters who are more frustrated than ennobled, Dance Me Outside deftly turns a number of narrative conventions upside down.

At 153 minutes, the movie does occasionally flirt with tedium, but the risk is worth it: The whole is finally greater than the sum of its pulpy parts. What could have been an anything-goes pastiche has surprising rigor and narrative clarity.
How much is fiction and how much is deliberate confusion?
Jonathan Demme's hypnotic adaptation of the Thomas Harris novel has a seriousness and intensity that's been entirely lacking in horror movies lately.
Andrew Bergman's The Freshman is a charmed comedy, the kind of seemingly effortless movie in which everything falls neatly into place, as if ordained by nature.
It's perhaps the closest Disney has come to creating a consciously mythical entertainment in the style of Star Wars. Yet like that film it keeps its sense of humor and fun.
Men in Black is moderately amusing, well-constructed and mercifully short, but it fails to deliver on the zaniness of its first half.
For the most part, this is an exciting, engaging thriller, well-directed by Wolfgang Petersen.
The clash of cultures is harrowing and sometimes hilarious.
Lindholm justifies his confidence in a visual approach that's refreshingly realistic.
A cluttered, empty drama that uses (or tries to use) golf, painting, dinner-table prayers and fly-fishing as pathways to enlightenment. When that doesn't work, the filmmakers start preaching.
Worst of all, Dying Young is a love story about two people who don't seem to be in love with each other.

Julia Roberts, Kiefer Sutherland and Kevin Bacon all bring conviction to these scenes, and William Baldwin, as the most irresponsible of the students, continues to suggest an electric screen presence that rivals his brother Alec.
If you loved Wolfe's book, you may very well hate the movie. If you simply liked the novel, you may be simultaneously entertained and disappointed by what De Palma and Cristofer have done to it.
By emphasizing the human cost of the operation, Scahill and Rowling turn "blowback" into much more than an abstract military-political term.
It's sometimes a mishmash, though never an unwelcome one.
movie_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An Australian mystery-thriller dominated by Joel Edgerton's fearless performance as a compromised married man.
The Next Karate Kid is harmless as children's entertainment, but for 104 very long minutes, there isn't a recognizable human being in sight.
Sometimes it takes a feature-length documentary to stitch together a story we think we already know.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Starts out as a raunchy teen comedy, slips into nature-epic mode, then adds a romantic triangle and finally finds a comfort zone in family-sitcom land.
The original film's director, Charles Martin Smith... has been replaced by Richard Martin, who brings a family-hour blandness to every scene.
The new summer movies don't get much more formulaic than this bald attempt to capture the audience that can't wait to see the next three or four installments of Home Alone.
If you think of movies as big-screen video games, see Fire Birds. If not, you may want to skip this Top Gun with copters and cartels.
Sweet and airy and pleasantly nostalgic, Jason Priestley's first starring vehicle is cotton-candy entertainment for summer's end.
Ghost Dad may be the dumbest major-studio movie of this none-too-bright summer.
The travelogue-style photography is soothing, the bodies are pretty and the music isn't offensive, but feature-length movies can't survive on the ingredients for a standard airline commercial.
A very odd, expensive, ambitious failure that tries hard to achieve the Spielberg touch but succeeds only in reminding you of how few filmmakers can successfully lay claim to his territory.
Bale and Menken are literally what make the movie sing.
Mundane sex scenes, a standard L.A. car chase and Bakula's outrageously gory death scene (which plays like an unintentional parody) are all part of the predictable script.
This is one of the summer's sorrier excuses for a major-studio release.
Klein and Seydoux give such naturalistic performances that they're never overwhelmed by the spectacle.
With its snazzy Elmer Bernstein score, its snappy period flavor and its all-star cast doing something completely different, A Rage in Harlem should have been much more fun than it is.
Several decades later, it still chills.
Plenty of clips from Plympton classics demonstrate why friends and fans have been rounded up to honor him.
Based on the true story of Leopold Socha, a Catholic Polish sewer worker who hid a group of Jews over a period of 14 months in the underground tunnels of Lvov.

Remarkably sexy for its genre (it's not for kids at all), it's nostalgic about a time and place that rarely gets treated on film ("Godfather II" touched on it), and it has an emotional pull that may catch you by surprise.
Garriott's story is unique, a stranger-than-fiction tale that is unlikely to be topped. And the images from space - crisp, spectacular, haunting - make it worth the trip.
movie_title: Richard Garriott: Man on a Mission (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Their anecdotes about Ray's creation of a filmmaking commune are vivid and affectionate, and they're punctuated with material from the film that is sometimes alarming but always informative.
It's the kind of would-be groundbreaker that continues to stir interest long after its failure as a theatrical release.
Partly a courtroom drama, partly a political satire and partly a twisty thriller that gradually draws you in and becomes more engrossing with each new revelation.
Sarkozy seems to mean exactly what he says, even when he's lying for his cause, and Podalyd√®s has the skill to demonstrate that.
For long stretches, it appears to be a road movie headed nowhere. Still, the detours it uncovers are fascinating.
A showcase for many conflicting viewpoints.
The filmmakers may not explain everything that passes before their cameras (why is caterpillar fungus such a hot commodity?), but that's part of the intrigue in this vanishing way of life.

If the script ultimately seems a bit extreme (are there no immediate consequences for Joseph's tantrums or the criminal outbursts of Hannah's abusive husband?), it's often surprisingly successful in pushing the limits of British kitchen-sink drama.
For a movie that deals with suicide, homelessness and cocaine addiction, writer-director Paul Weitz's latest family drama feels strangely bland.
The movie is dense with witty visual detail that helps to distract from the somewhat trumped-up moral dilemma at its center.
There's something profoundly inspirational about this portrait of a community coming together to battle prejudice and disease.

Tykwer's script is structured so that the audience knows more about the characters' connections than they do. As each faces a midlife crisis/turning point, fate sometimes appears to be calling the shots.

Cullen and New are British stage actors with little background in film. Haigh's only previous film was a documentary. Perhaps because they don't feel bound by a set of rules, they've created one of the year's most enjoyable surprises.

The director, Jonathan Segal, skillfully builds on the tension that this situation creates, though he can't quite make Wingate's ending click. Still, Segal is so good with his actors that you may not mind.
The movie is all over the place, searching for an identity that proves almost entirely elusive.
It's so stunningly effective at establishing a sense of dread that it's almost impossible to recommend it without reservations.
The filmmakers didn't have a lot of options. In some ways the new picture feels like a boxed-in replay.
This low-budget movie takes its time filling in the backgrounds of its characters. That works for a while, but when it's over you may wonder if that's all there is.
One long, extensively choreographed fight sequence in which "mortal" blows are delivered so often, and with so little lasting impact, that a brawl just becomes a brawl becomes a brawl.
It starts slowly, then develops an irresistible momentum.
An unexpectedly droll tale about a funeral, "Nora's Will" demonstrates the power of some people to reach beyond the grave.
Lillard - an actor best-known for his role in "The Descendants" - uses the locations well enough, but the result is still a standard coming-of-age picture.
Where did Melancholia come from? It's best not to ask. The explanation for the planet's origins is so preposterous that veteran science-fiction writers everywhere must be rolling their eyes.
"Boy," from New Zealand, has its charms, most of them to do with Boy, an 11-year-old pop-culture enthusiast who's obsessed with Michael Jackson and moonwalking.
By the end, with the running time pushing past the two-hour mark, it's reasonable to ask: Just who are these people?
movie_title: Detective Dee and the Mystery of the Phantom Flame (2011)

movie_review_blurb: While "They Call It Myanmar" is certainly more encouraging than previous films on this long-repressed country, fears of persecution continue to loom large.
movie_title: They Call It Myanmar: Lifting The Curtain (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A feast for the eyes and clearly a labor of love, "Flight of the Butterflies" is one of the must-see 3-D IMAX movies.
The only entertaining touches are Drew's interactions with visitors or bystanders who are shocked by his behavior. The rest is simply interminable.
This dreamy, visually inventive Iranian drama functions on so many levels of reality and obsession that it almost ceases to entertain.
An accomplished indie filmmaker ("Forty Shades of Blue"), Sachs creates a genuinely romantic bond between his actors that feels fresh and free of clich√©s.
While the movie itself is an uneven, sometimes preachy affair, it's alive with possibilities whenever [Weston's] on screen.
movie_title: The Brooklyn Brothers Beat The Best (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A sprawling, initially engaging French comedy-drama that became a hit in France but ultimately underwhelms.
The movie needs a tighter grip, yet the narrative detours, including a beach party and one especially liberating confrontation, can be surprisingly joyous.
The picture sometimes seems to have been assembled rather than creatively edited.
"Side by Side" is a kind of eulogy for celluloid, beginning with some of the most famous images committed to film: "A Trip to the Moon," "Citizen Kane," "The Wizard of Oz."
Skips around the decades, taking a minimalist approach to history - mostly by demonstrating how recent traumatic events have inconvenienced the love lives of its central characters.
The catalog of horrors occasionally feels incomplete (who's holding the camera in the most intimate scenes?), but the movie does an exceptional job of expanding on its narrow focus.
The movie frequently clicks as a sendup of over-the-top film-noir storytelling.
A serious, moving and sometimes astonishingly well-organized documentary about the history of AIDS activism.
Wisemen's film is a soulless mess, reminiscent of the unwatchable "Matrix" sequels, while Verhoeven's movie remains a dazzling carnival.
Featuring a Bollywood subplot and an irresistible East-meets-West score, the movie is lush and lusty: both a strong vehicle for Pinto and a good match for Winterbottom's impressionistic style.

Zvyaginstsev makes the most of the ghastly settings, which include a backyard that ominously features nuclear cones - and the kinds of compartmentalized living spaces that Hitchcock used for droll effect in "Rear Window."
[It] often feels thin and self-conscious.
This enigmatic coming-of-age movie often seems destined to sail off the deep end. Yet it rights itself just often enough to keep you watching.
If it were any shorter, it would lack depth. If it were any longer, it would most likely seem a strain. As is, there's an emotional honesty here that registers quickly and often.
Bouquet and the waterways of Venice are the chief charms of T√©chin√©'s movie, which is otherwise one of his less convincing efforts.
Whatever you think of it, you won't be neutral.
A witty, well-cast, sometimes ingeniously paced political comedy.
Climate-change documentaries are almost always disturbing, but "The Island President" communicates a special urgency.
"Monsieur Lazhar" is a complex, multilayered tale that reveals new meanings as it introduces each new character.
Resembles a movie less than it suggests an evening of determined, incoherent channel-hopping - with the help of a remote control that's apparently stuck on "random."
Much of "Force of Nature" feels familiar and unnecessarily predigested.
movie_title: Force of Nature: The David Suzuki Movie (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The plot is as incomprehensible as the dubbing, and many of the special effects are neither special nor effective.
I doubt that Kurt Russell has ever had less dialogue to work with than he has in this film.

It is superbly executed and, for all its pitilessness, it's an intelligent dramatization of the impact that consumerist values have had on the psyche of the North American middle class at the end of the 20th century.
As a satire on the only true religion of the American South -- football -- The Waterboy is delightful.
Even the audience at the free promotional screening was hard-pressed to find many genuine laughs in this purportedly comic abomination.
A promising premise leads to only mildly effective romantic dramedy.
movie_title: Seeking a Friend for the End of the World (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Stars Smith and Jones deliver a few scenes of enjoyably antagonistic banter but neither seems as fully committed to this kind of comedy as in the earlier films.
Soderbergh gives the film a distinctive look and an almost verit√© feel that produces some effective sequences over the story's early stages.
Mendes is appealing as the childlike Grace and Ramirez shows real promise as the serious-minded Ansiedad.
This high-concept Eddie Murphy vehicle is weak even by the low standards of the star's recent output.
An efficiently twisty thriller that goes for the same internationally-flavoured blend of brutal action and dramatic intrigue as the Jason Bourne films.
A real life-based drama that's pleasantly warm but overly busy and short on emotional oomph.
Several of the segments make up for their lack of polish with a clear relish for their genre.
Leth spins out the mystery quite effectively and while he's doing so introduces a number of other elements that keep the film entertaining.
The main attraction is still a string of inevitable and grisly deaths; but this time the effects are better and there's some actual drama and comedy between the send-offs.
With its messy script and weirdly edgy tone, The Sitter, a third straight R-rated comedy from one-time art house auteur David Gordon Green, is an oddity even by the standards of its own genre.
Montiel does a skilful job intertwining the past and present action but the plot always feels thin and the characters underdeveloped.
A few flashes of vintage Eddie Murphy liven up Tower Heist, an otherwise mild-mannered action comedy carried by nice-guy lead Ben Stiller.
The lead performances feel a bit restrained as the stars struggle to find a balance between comic exaggeration and dramatic realism.

While it may not have the force of Sam Peckinpah's 1971 original, writer-director Rod Lurie's redo of Straw Dogs still holds up as an entertaining thriller with more than just shock value on its mind.
The Help is a nicely cast but otherwise pedestrian adaptation of Kathryn Stockett's best-selling 2009 novel.
Feels like two fairly generic movies that don't quite add to up to more than the sum of their parts.
Timothy's own destiny is flagged fairly early on, leaving the story nowhere much to go.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Friends With Benefits talks like an adult but acts like a teen. The clash between perky style and verbally risque content detracts from the appeal of a strong cast led by Justin Timberlake and Mila Kunis.
The ensemble produces some decent laughs.
A serviceable thriller with a fast pace but not much of the grit and humour that set the original apart.
The long-delayed remake of John Milius' 1984 Cold War drama Red Dawn turns out to be heavy on noisy action and light on almost everything else, including plot development and dramatic tension.
Adds some slightly dodgy new elements to the mix but still delivers what should be enough macho swagger and over-the-top auto action to keep fans of the franchise happy.

Boasting a classy ensemble cast and an eye catching look, true crime tale Gangster Squad does an entertaining job telling the story of a band of cops who reclaim late forties Los Angeles from ruthless mobster Mickey Cohen.
More fun as a red band trailer than as a feature, We're The Millers scatters a handful of raucously funny scenes across nearly two hours of softer family themed comedy.
Gyllenhaal brings essential emotional weight to the story and he's backed by a strong supporting cast.
A fitfully intriguing but ultimately aimless psychosexual thriller about pretty young things behaving badly in Hollywood.
Hybrid specialist Raja Gosnell returns as director and ably delivers slapstick comedy for the kids and nicely shot views of Paris landmarks for the adults.
A smart, refreshingly frank though only moderately funny coming of age tale about an uptight high schooler and her quest for sexual experience.
When it goes for the kind of winking humour that gave the original much of its charm the sequel feels forced rather than refreshing.
Director Glenn Gaylord and director of photography David Morris Gil (shooting his first feature) give the film a nicely autumnal New York.
The film meanders agreeably enough through its predictable plot but takes a bit too much time out for facile life lessons and admiring depictions of Google's corporate culture.
Brings Todd Phillips' R-rated guys-night-out trilogy to an oddly subdued, sometimes downright dark conclusion.

Though it sometimes wears its influences a tad too openly, Dead Man's Burden is still an atmospheric and emotionally satisfying indie western that could spark interest among serious fans of the genre.
The film feels subdued and a little stiff, as if afraid to add too much drama or cinematic style to the historical facts.
A ponderous and at times pretty silly romantic sci-fi adventure.
Neither the on- nor off-screen talent can spark much life into this self-consciously moody revenge tale, which ends up feeling like a strained exercise in seventies neo-noir revivalism.
British director Peter Webber spins out the political intrigue quite effectively.
The film's first half is weighed down by clich√©d dialogue and clunky drama.
Hough is reasonably appealing in her first dramatic role but she doesn't uncover anything very interesting in the cute yet fragile Katie.
Giving a rom-com twist to the always reliable zombie genre, Warm Bodies turns a cute premise into a mildly affecting story of forbidden teen love.
The elements don't combine to any great effect, leaving this adaptation from the work of pulp novelist Donald Westlake feeling lacklustre and a bit old fashioned.
Marlon Wayans takes comedic aim at Paranormal Activity and its ilk but scores precious few hits.
The climactic half-hour offers lively gunplay and car chases as well as some amusing -- and amusingly violent -- moments.
Gordon-Levitt is, as usual, a likeable hero, though he's underused in a film that's plainly more interested in kinetics than drama.
[Rise Of The Guardians] provides plenty of action and colour for younger kids but rarely builds up the sort of emotional momentum necessary to grab the rest of the family.
An efficiently staged but credibility-stretching international thriller that never quite lives up to its Hitchcockian potential.
After its breezy first act the film goes into a second act that's intended to be darker and more dramatic but doesn't convince on either count.
The 3D cinematography is occasionally impressive, but in most other respects Australian made cave-diving adventure Sanctum is a disappointingly hackneyed genre outing.
Muscular but pretty unimaginative.
Even with Doomsday's Rhona Mitra as a replacement sultry presence, it's likely to disappoint the franchise's core audience of young males.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: What follows has the comforting predictability that many rom-coms share.
While kids will get a few giggles out of this scattershot Disney fantasy-comedy, adults probably won't find much to laugh at.
A slow, improbable and very mawkish drama.

The standout acting performance comes from Wright, who, though he doesn't look particularly like Waters, captures some of the singer's physicality and delivers some poignant moments as the great bluesman begins to lose his commercial mojo.
Four rounds of family festivities produce very little merriment for either its protagonists or audiences.
The film settles into a pattern of predictable romance interspersed, thanks to the antics of Priya's relations, with broad family farce.
movie_title: The Other End of the Line (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The sequel to DreamWorks' computer-animated family hit Madagascar offers more drama and a lot more animals but fewer laughs and not quite as much fun as the colourful summer 2005 original.
Anderson finds a few interesting angles from which to cover things, but there's nothing really memorable or original to wow jaded action fans.
Maximum violence and minimum plot are the formula.
Smith still manages to find something touching and occasionally even tragic in the character.
The moments don't add up to much, though, and the dramatic arc ends up feeling even narrower than it usually is in this kind of story.
The comedy, though, is broad and only mildly effective and the banter lacks edge and wit.
Strong new characters are disappointingly thin on the ground.
While it doesn't work particularly well on any of those levels, it is a colourful addition to the always popular talking dog genre.
Produces some real laughs but was probably more fun to make than it ultimately is to watch.
The vampire's attacks are nicely manic - think of an over-zealous contestant at a pie eating contest -- but they get repetitive after the first few kills.
The same kind of lightweight but well executed comic book-based romp as its predecessor.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Offers plenty of blood but not much of the rocker-turned-filmmaker's usual gory flair.
You would expect a mostly British legal thriller to be somewhat reserved, but Closed Circuit, while predictably classy and intelligently topical, is a little too chilly for its own good.
Even avid fans of the classic video game on which it is based are likely to give a thumbs down to Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li.
movie_title: Street Fighter: The Legend of Chun-Li (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not surprisingly, Joel and Ethan Coen's True Grit is leaner, meaner and funnier than the 1969 John Wayne Western that first put grizzled US Marshal Rooster Cogburn on screen.
A Judd Apatow-esque mix of the buddy and romantic comedy genres, I Love You, Man hits the funny bone often if never particularly hard.
A self-consciously crazy action romp which overdoses on cartoonish violence and non-PC comedy.
Even Nicholson's usually scene-stealing bluster can't get this disappointing addition to the Brooks filmography going.
The male leads look comfortable in roles that approximate to their usual comic personas and each deliver chuckle-worthy moments.
The film sometimes gets dangerously close to vintage Hollywood sword 'n' sandal territory, with American-accented Romans and much manly jaw clenching by Tatum and Bell.

More interested in theology than gut-churning effects, The Rite is a creepy exorcism thriller elevated a bit above the norm for that reliable genre by a classy look and the gravitas of star Anthony Hopkins.
Halle Berry impresses in both the title roles of Frankie & Alice, a well crafted if slightly soapy seventies period piece about a young woman's struggle with multiple personality disorder.
Michael Apted keeps the story moving and finds more humour in the adventure than was offered in the darker Caspian installment.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Voyage of the Dawn Treader (2010)

movie_review_blurb: It's an intriguing story grippingly told, though the film doesn't quite have the force or universality of earlier Gibney documentaries.
movie_title: Client 9: The Rise and Fall of Eliot Spitzer (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A couple of touching moments aside, Valentine's Day is as blatantly engineered and resolutely frothy as mid-February date movies get.
Dear John emerges on the big screen as a good looking but dull romance directed with a little too much restraint by Lasse Hallstrom.
A serviceable but uninspired romantic comedy with a familiar fishes-out-of-water backdrop.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There are no new tricks in Old Dogs, a broad and frenetic family comedy which puts John Travolta and Robin Williams together with two cute kids in a cozily predictable family-comes-first scenario.
Independently and internationally produced CG animated comedy Planet 51 has the visuals to compare with bigger budgeted Hollywood studio offerings but not the storytelling spark.
While there are some imaginative effects and spooky moments (as well as a few hackneyed sci-fi touches) the whole thing gets pretty silly at times, and the mystery is never fully resolved.

A Christmas Carol is an engaging and relatively dark take on a seasonal classic that finds director Robert Zemeckis refining the performance capture animation technique he used to mixed effect on The Polar Express and Beowulf.
Over-acting is endemic. Quaid can't do much with his very limited role, and Foster seems miscast.
While the film isn't as consistently funny as Borat, Bruno should still pull in a sizeable audience.
An awkwardly structured but warmly emotional and relatively unsentimental drama.
Sweet yet slight.
None of the actors has much to work with but Worthington and Yelchin manage to give their characters some appeal. Bale's Connor is too gruff and one-note to be of much interest.
Starts unpromisingly but ends up, thanks largely to co-star Jennifer Garner, being briefly affecting.
As a study of two apparently dissimilar men trying to find their way in the world, The Soloist works fairly well.
Ambitious but overwrought.
A potent mix of suspense, emotion and intrigue that draws intense performances from leads Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal.

It won't make many new converts, but Adam Sandler fans will be plenty happy with Jack And Jill, a broad and endearingly loopy family comedy in which Sandler stars alongside himself (in drag) and, even more bizarrely, Al Pacino playing himself.
A wildly contrived but pleasantly frothy romcom about a youngish single woman on an urgent search for Mr Right.

While the franchise's twentieth entry... is certainly not vintage Bond, it does come equipped with the requisite supply of furious action and, in Oscar-winner Halle Berry, perhaps the highest-profile Bond Girl in the franchise's history.

The Intern eventually manages - with the help of admirably game performances from Robert DeNiro and Anne Hathaway - to find something worth saying about Millennial generation women and men and their baby boomer forebears.
Feels like a strangely squandered opportunity.

The storytelling techniques work well enough to keep the film engaging - though having characters read out messages as they type them gets annoying pretty quickly - and Scott keeps the pacing breezy and relatively light.
An efficient yet uninspiring sequel to last year's successful young adult novel adaptation The Maze Runner.
A breezy but touching dysfunctional family dramedy, with real heart and some genuine musical soul.
It turns into a considerably more intriguing and twisty psychological drama with a distinctly European flavour ...
While the package should be amply attractive to a broad family audience, what's inside it might prove a bit tame for many adults and not enough fun for kids ...
In its final hour, Inception becomes more conventional and less imaginative. The rules of the dreamworld still frame the action, but they provide fewer surprises, for the team or the audience.
Thankfully, Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge Of The Sith has a good deal to offer besides its cachet as the farewell to a pop culture.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A curiously ponderous affair, with an excess of pop psychology character background and cod-Eastern mysticism and not enough fun or action.
Tangerine paints a portrait of transgender sex workers and their clients that pulses with raunchy energy and compassionate humour.
A genial if somewhat old-fashioned tale that's too clunky to transcend its genre(s) but effective enough within its own limited emotional range.
A forced and often cloying romantic comedy-drama with a strong, Bradley Cooper-led cast and an enticing Hawaiian setting but a bewildering mishmash of plot threads and themes.
The very earnest human drama fits awkwardly into the action and isn't helped by some unconvincing performances and weak dialogue.
The script, by TV comedy writers Jay Martel and Ian Roberts, doesn't give the stars much to work with and their apparent improvisation is only fleetingly effective.

Even if it doesn't earn the sci-fi adventure franchise many new converts, Insurgent should retain the fan base created by last year's Divergent and keep it primed for the series' two-part Allegiant finale.
While the dramatic themes echo the great crime movies of the seventies, it's the modern flash and muscle that ultimately win out in this pacey yet less than satisfying action thriller.
The story has a pleasant warmth to it - together with a vague message about individuality and tolerance - and Parsons does a terrific job bringing the charmingly open-hearted Oh to life.
The supporting cast takes some of the comic weight off the always likeable Vaughn's shoulders. But Wilkinson's character is too sad-sack to be really funny and Franco's verges on the mawkish.
Recalling everything from Paranormal Activity to Prom Night to The Phantom of the Opera, high school-set found-footage horror yarn The Gallows offers up few new ideas and very few genuine scares.
The film itself is frustratingly inconsistent and never finds a rhythm to carry it from scene to scene.
A likeable if lightweight indie dramedy about a messed-up New Orleans superhero and his cranky, wheelchair-bound best friend.

With a script that's about as inventive as the title, Ride Along 2 does little more than rehash the formula that two years ago teamed Ice Cube and Kevin Hart in an amiable if unambitious action comedy.
A number of sequences in the story ... feel inevitable rather than organic.
When it does get down to superheroine business, this latest DC Comics 'extended universe' outing packs a decent punch and, in Israeli model Gal Gadot, introduces a star with real franchise potential.
Manages to put a bit of wind back in the sails; though not enough to return the franchise to its swashbuckling best.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Hyperactive, oddly premised and never quite as endearing as it should be, The Boss Baby is an animated family comedy that seems to have all the right elements but just doesn't deliver.
Retro horror and racial tension mix to surprisingly entertaining effect in Get Out, the feature directing debut of US TV comedy multi-hyphenate Jordan Peele.
An entertaining yarn that's never less than watchable, even if it pales in comparison to more charged true(ish) stories like American Hustle and McConaughey's own Dallas Buyers Club.

Part space romance, part space thriller and all space corn, Passengers is a messy and unconvincing mash-up that tries to get by on the not inconsiderable charm of stars Jennifer Lawrence and Chris Pratt.
The debauchery doesn't get close to the inspired heights visited in The Hangover and other more enthusiastically raucous movies.
Before long, this disappointingly limp thriller devolves into something much more generic, relying on slasher movie tropes and a wildly improbable plot twist for its effect.
The film often feels flat when it should be light-footed.
A peppy CG outing more suited to younger kids than anyone looking for real drama or heart.

The third instalment of the re-booted Star Trek franchise gets safely through its voyage, offering a strong returning cast and a familiar, if slightly tweaked mix of effects-heavy space action, cheeky humour and philosophical musing.
A run-of-the-mill zombie flick that goes through the genre motions efficiently enough but fails to live up to its credits.
A colourful 3D romp that's heavy on slapstick and cosy family comedy but light on real laughs and affecting drama.
Unconvincing and generic, with nothing to compare to either the dramatic heft of Peter Jackson's Lord of the Rings trilogy or the raunch and gore of Game of Thrones.
In the end the film comes up with an almost humanist definition of miracles and their cause.

Though there's some clunky dialogue and not much real character development, Reynolds manages to put the action, mystery and drama elements together into a credible, and at times quite touching whole.

This must be what a French movie-of-the-week look like, deemed art here because of the subtitles.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Using the opera's timeless whimsy and inventiveness, the movie replicates a performance on the stage that is so good that it almost makes you forget the participants' ABBA-like hairstyles.
The movie has elements of Gothic horror and philosophy, along with lusty, low comedy rolls.
Its view of a seemingly godless landscape in the grip of plague is still bold and frightening.
Thou shalt not cast Christian Slater as Moses, no matter how much the Hollywood party boy wants to fulfill some form of karmic community service.
Even when it resorts to the hoariest clich√©s, 30 Days of Night still chills.
Fessenden, who directed, produced, cowrote, edited and even has a part in the film rightly values mood at least as much as he does delivering more abominable snow monsters.
Perry's comedy will likely never be breezy, and the film drags through its second hour.
The Devil Came on Horseback is a documentary account of Steidle's ongoing efforts to educate the world about the violence he witnessed as an unarmed military observer for the African Union in 2004.
For whatever reason you go to a movie like this, the results are bound to disappoint.
Marketed as a family-friendly adventure about a kid with magical powers, this adaptation of Susan Cooper's Newbery Award-winning book is hopelessly glum.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: This is heart-wrenching Indian drama in the vein of Deepa Mehta's recent Water, again dealing with a young girl trying to find her self-worth in the midst of a repressive caste system and physical abuse.
A Disney comedy that tries to overcompensate with cute what it lacks in clever.
The movie is crisply shot and obviously heartfelt, but search elsewhere if you want the same honesty Hawke displayed as an actor in 1995's Before Sunrise and its 2004 sequel Before Sunset.
With a keen eye for wide-screen imagery, Kohn captures the personalities of his interview subjects.

This is not your middle-schooler's Amanda Bynes. While her female fans will appreciate that 21-year-old Bynes is growing up with them, maybe her next movie will stretch beyond the fractured fairy tale.
More of the same game.
A desperately unfunny mix of romantic and gross-out comedy.

The only winners in Dragon Wars are the computer-imaging geeks who must have logged tons of overtime. The rest of the world is left scratching its head at a monster epic so dismal that it doesn't even register as a guilty pleasure.
There is no I in "team," but there are three in "idiotic." And idiotic more or less describes the appeal of The Comebacks, a so-stupid-it's-funny spoof of inspirational sports dramas.
Excellent performances by everyone involved help you overlook the incongruity of French-speaking actors in traditional English settings.
Confessional moments and life lessons pop up around every corner as the movie swaps reality for old-fashioned melodrama. The movie defies logic.
The most poignant, well-acted and weirdly funny movie you'll see this year.
12:08 East of Bucharest is easier to admire than enjoy, funnier to describe than actually watch.
movie_title: 12:08 East of Bucharest (A fost sau n-a fost?) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: What could have been an epic Disney misfire is saved by the charming Adams.
What better way to spend 97 minutes in November than trying to sort out romantic complications in shorts and sailboats?
Hopelessly misguided.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Cult movies have been made with a lot less, but this one, harmless enough, doesn't have enough originality or personality to get it off the ground.
Does the movie glorify Barnes and his nefarious profession? Probably, but show me a movie about the drug trade that doesn't hook us first with guts and glamour before the moralizing fall.
Even by the low standards of the horror subgenre playfully nicknamed "torture porn," P2 is scraping the bottom of the movie barrel.
The eggnog quickly turns sour as the movie alternates between moments both heartwarming and bizarre.
The movie can also be accused of its own sugar overdose as director Menno Meyjes piles on every clich√©d situation.
More than a standard child prodigy profile, My Kid Could Paint That turns into a priceless examination of modern art, celebrity and what it means to be a kid.
The future of Wristcutters as a cult favorite is less assured. Rather than benefiting from repeated viewings, the movie's charm is pretty much spent after the first half hour.
The dullest Saw in the shed.
Plagues and Pleasures is simultaneously fun and creepy, best appreciated by those who enjoy similar profiles of Detroit's crumbling grandeur.
movie_title: Plagues & Pleasures on the Salton Sea (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately, its superb performances and assured camerawork are overwhelmed by dubious psychology and a clich√©d climax.
As good as Melville's setups are, the joys of the movie keep returning to Belmondo, then and now the king of effortless cool.
While the low-budget comedy is occasionally charming, it mostly fails in clumsy attempts at evoking laughs and tears.
The movie claims the 'God inside me' concept is rooted in compassion, but it plays like nondenominational narcissism to me.
The movie is warped, to be sure, but even fans will have to admit that the laughs are stretched pretty thin over nearly 90 minutes.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: These guys don't much about making movies, but they know how to stage a smack down.
In terms of raw, heart-thumping action, The Transporter 2 out-Bonds Bond.
The filmmakers of A Sound of Thunder, like a T. rex with indigestion, have simply bitten off more than they could chew.
Underclassman is squarely aimed at a teen audience, but will be best appreciated by those who have never seen a TV cop show or, better yet, never attended school.
Is The Cave scary? Not especially, partly due to the creatures' goofy sound effects.
Chaos will likely find an audience based on its infamy as the most brutal film ever made. Yet I don't think I'd like to meet anyone who would subject himself to this thing willingly.
Even young viewers will recognize Valiant as second-tier Disney.
It would be easy to dismiss The Seat Filler as a by-the-numbers romantic comedy, the only difference being its mostly black cast.
Just call it Hustle and Low.
The image of Campbell slapping himself to the ground is the only gag that the movie doesn't beat to death.
Thanks to Riegert's obvious passion for the project, it succeeds even when individual scenes play like bits from an actors' workshop.
Herbie is the kind of funny, frenetic family movie that really does offer something for everyone.
Add Heather Locklear to the list of strikingly beautiful actresses who somehow can't get a date on screen. That's the shaky premise of The Perfect Man.
Parkhill tries to keep new blood pulsing through the film, but the movie stalls by its third act, where he plays a trick that seems more desperate than fresh.
Elon uses quiet and silence to great effect.
Surprisingly fresh and entertaining.
The Man is so slapdash that two major characters are revealed to be the same person, a move prompted more by budgetary concerns than clever scripting.
Less talk. More head spinning. These are the charges against The Exorcism of Emily Rose, which delivers some creepy moments but only after endless scenes of courtroom wrangling.
Intelligent, entertaining and, yes, educational as it looks at the nature of political activism now and then.
The makers of Saw II have taken great pains to hide the twist ending to the film. I'd love to reveal it out of spite, only because it hints that I'll be sitting through another Saw sequel next year.
There's a good movie to be made about the violent world of British soccer, or football, as it's called on the other side of the pond. This isn't it.
The movie may lose some of its bite when translated from page to screen, but it still delivers a valid message. When one of the boys starts reading good literature, life takes on new meaning.
movie_title: Balzac and the Little Chinese Seamstress (2005)

movie_review_blurb: When the video game-to-movie thing becomes this literal, it only makes you wonder why anyone would want to see a big-screen Doom at all.
While Cote d'Azur should be a vacation, it's often more like work just trying to stay engaged.
Caterina in the City is a coming-of-age story, of course, but its adult characters are also well rendered.
I'm not a gambling man, but I bet I haven't fidgeted this much in a theater all year.
This may not be the greatest golf movie ever made, but it's head and shoulders above other recent screen treatments of the sport.
It cleverly re-creates what it must have felt like to walk in the astronauts' weighted boots.
movie_title: Magnificent Desolation: Walking on the Moon 3D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A loyal gay audience may appreciate the novelty, but horror fans can find junk like this lining the shelves of any video store.
Roll Bounce drags a little in its second hour, but it is also a rare movie that genuinely likes its characters. You will too.
El Crimen Perfecto loses some steam in the final quarter, but still has enough style to make you want to see how it all shakes out.
movie_title: The Perfect Crime (El Crimen Perfecto)(Crimen ferpecto) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The Baxter has many of the ingredients of a good-natured indie date movie. But when the lead performance isn't one of them, it gets difficult to recommend.
The movie clunks along much like its leads, never exactly sure where they belong.
Venom is even more pointless than most supernatural slasher movies.
The first film in terms of Oscar hopefuls this year that can truly be considered a contender.
Sometimes it is only slightly more mature than your average vehicle for the Olsen twins.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The intentions are admirable, but the movie is only so-so.
Wildly entertaining.
Imaginary Heroes mines the suburban tragedy of Ordinary People, The Ice Storm and American Beauty, but with only a quarter of the insight.
A solid, emotionally charged picture that bridges a gap between German expressionism and poetic realism.
The Pacifier falls into the same category as Are We There Yet? which gave Ice Cube a similar baby-sitting gig with equally dreadful results.
Only gets into serious trouble when it focuses on human interaction. That's because directors Moon-saeng Kim and Park Sunmin have populated the movie with every stereotype in Asian animation.
Parents who claim they crave thoughtful entertainment for their kids finally have a movie they can get behind.
You can rightly say that Jaa has yet to establish much of a character, but give him a chance.
Sure, this should be straight-to-video Disney, but it's still charming, harmless fun.
A moving experience.
It turns into a subtle character study that both gay and straight audiences will find moving.
Even if we could buy the contrived setup (right: Debra Messing needs to buy a date), there is no thought to fleshing out the characters.
It's tempting to call Alone in the Dark one of those movies so bad that it's almost good. But that might send the wrong signal to Hollywood.

The second half gets downright silly as the country home turns into a slaughterhouse. What could have been a Sixth Sense-style intelligent thriller heads straight for the drive-in, though it's still handled with considerable skill.
Diehard horror fans may want to weigh in. The rest can see it soon at the video store.
Worse than the crude humor is the movie's forced sentiment.
Even by the dubious standards of talking animal movies, this one is routine.
Ultimately stumbles in its mission to make the founding of the Mormon religion interesting to a general audience.
The book was about class and the American dream. The movie is too, though it's most interested in the soap opera machinations of the plot.
Likable but poorly crafted.
At heart, this is just another rehash of Meet the Parents.
... barely watchable.
Neither as funny nor as sexy as it promises to be.
3-Iron may not be a horror movie, but it is still haunting.
A guaranteed tearjerker.
Just formula entertainment, classy but still trite.
The acting in House of Wax is as horrible as you might expect.
Charming, intelligent entertainment that should attract the same family audiences that flocked to Winged Migration in 2001.
movie_title: The Wild Parrots of Telegraph Hill (2005)

movie_review_blurb: One of the few movies where the word 'awesome' truly applies.
This is just a warm-up as the summer movie season gets an early start. Big, loud and stupid, XXX: State of the Union isn't so much a sequel as a preview of coming attractions.
It's cute enough but fails to deliver.
A throwaway date movie, but with enough quirky touches to almost make it worth recommending.
Ostensibly about the aftermath of apartheid, but the pain of a people serves only as a backdrop for the most contrived of love stories.
As with Step into Liquid, Brown proves in Dust to Glory that the thrill of high-speed racing can be shared by fans and non-fans alike.
Still a classic example of eye-popping excess at a time when German filmmakers were among the most innovative in the world.
The latest in a long line of cheap horror film remakes that combine familiar names and stories with slash-cut editing and computer-generated effects.
Like most sequels, Miss Congeniality 2 is just a dumbed-down version of a concept that wasn't that bright to begin with.
Not every joke connects, but Gore and director Philip Zlotorynski make sure that five more are waiting around the corner.
While most mockumentaries translate as lazy storytelling, this one is elevated by an astounding, Oscar-worthy performance by Kaye.
Loggerheads has the best qualities of independent filmmaking.
NASCAR fans will likely love Talladega Nights, which may be a glowing endorsement or a warning sign, depending on the viewer.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: You genuinely care about the six women who enter a cave in the Appalachian mountains, only to discover it crawling with flesh-eating predators who have adapted to life in the dark.
Poorly animated and barely scripted, this is the worst in an endless line of computer-animated movies starring animals this year.
A movie about spiritual awakening that plays like a spliced-together string of New Age fortune cookie messages.
Capably accomplishes its mission to Mars by blending solid science with sci-fi eye candy.
There's nothing horribly wrong with Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An hour into the movie, I shut out the story and dialogue entirely and just focused on the visuals. That made the boring Bell and the cast of third-string teen movie supporting players somehow easier to bear.

Think of the countless car chases you've seen at the movies. Then catch Tokyo Drift to understand how this movie, as silly as it is, offers something different and fresh. For fans of the genre, that's a stunt worth getting revved up for.
movie_title: The Fast and the Furious: Tokyo Drift (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Though hardly a lost classic, the cartoon's irony-free approach and bizarre characters show why it resonates today.
Debut director Ricardo de Montreuil only cares about filming pretty people in the most hackneyed positions imaginable.
Its makers will tell you that Hoot is an educational film, but aside from showing that some owls live underground rather than in trees, little knowledge is actually imparted.
Stranded in this movie wasteland, you have to have fun with what you've got.
A sappy, redemption-soaked story about two Harlem-raised brothers that is as old as the Bible itself.
Scary Movie 4 is the rare movie spoof that's actually better than the titles it lampoons.
Everything here is beyond predictable.
movie_title: Goal! The Dream Begins (Goal!: The Impossible Dream) (2005)

movie_review_blurb: The movie charms while making a bold statement about the borders that governments and individuals construct to keep each other apart.
Dirty Dancing by way of 8 Mile might be the best way to describe Step Up, a likable, predictable musical drama.
Like a mediocre high school transcript, the movie has the foundations, but it skimps on the extracurriculars.
Guide gets the details right, recalling the minutiae of Dito's teen years -- from clothes to conversations -- with near-psychoanalytical clarity.
movie_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints (2006)

movie_review_blurb: For a movie about taking pride in your work, Employee of the Month is on a comedy coffee break.
Some theaters are showing the movie in IMAX 3D, which is the way I saw it. The novelty helps, but it still can't bring depth to entertainment this shallow.
Just as outrageous as fans were hoping it would be.
The 43-year-old actor claims that this will be his last martial arts epic. That's too bad when movies like this and 2002's Hero find him just hitting his stride.
movie_title: Jet Li's Fearless (Huo Yuan Jia) (Legend of a Fighter) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Place it squarely in the category of overlooked gems.
If Tim Allen really was a superhero, his name would be Blandman. His power: turn even the most innocuous kiddie movie into something nearly unwatchable.
I don't pretend to understand the pressures facing U.S. troops in Iraq, but I feel a little closer after witnessing The Ground Truth.
Drawing Restraint 9 belongs to an endangered species of experimental film that walks the line between challenging and alienating its audience.
Plenty of punches get thrown in The Protector, but most left me numb.
Crossover expects moviegoers to ignore the inept script and acting and root for its characters anyway.
It may be one of the loudest, most obnoxious (not to mention sexist) movies of the summer, but damned if it doesn't keep an audience in high gear.
Somewhere in How to Eat Fried Worms is a message about keeping your word and the pitfalls of peer pressure.
Nonsensical from the get-go, the girls' fish-out-of-water routine grows interminable.
A likable, lumbering, computer-animated children's movie set during the Depression that is more entertaining than it has any right to be.
One of the most eccentric and fascinating vanity projects in the history of film.
[Chester] and the goofy Gets make a likable comedy team.
ATL may fail to wow on the skate floor, but it still makes decent melodrama.
The movie prefers to show snippets of life and let the audience make the connections. Many of these scenes prove memorable.
While you may have seen the story before, the offbeat characters and the movie location make you feel like you're treading new ground.
Even when skewering the pompousness of upper-class black mobility, it's still adorable.
Even if you still find the premise funny, how long can you laugh at this same sorry routine?
Wobbles unsteadily between a military recruitment vehicle and an underdog boxing picture.
Nanny McPhee is clever enough, but it never feels like it's hitting quite the right notes.
At Last would work a lot better with genuine chemistry between the leads, and maybe a bit more humor.
The production is sometimes so handsome, the scenery so compelling, that you almost forget about the melodramatic missteps and the bad wigs.
A computer-animated feature that maintains a moderate level of cleverness without being the least bit engaging.
Track down the old movie if you crave a real meal.
Grandma's Boy is a brain-dead stoner comedy from Happy Madison Productions that was coproduced by Adam Sandler. Rarely has so little been done with so little.
Hand much of the credit to director Rob Reiner, who consistently hits the right comic notes.
There's nothing like a bloated Hollywood misfire to teach us a lesson in corporate excess.
Even those viewers attracted to the mayhem promised by Yours, Mine and Ours will have to admit what a mess has been made of this kids-in-a-shoe family comedy.
Think of Just Friends as this season's answer to last year's Surviving Christmas, making you wonder what you did to deserve more movie coal in your stocking.

Final Destination 3 still falls squarely into the category of guilty pleasure, but it's fashioned with a fair amount of craft. If fate should bring us another installment, let's hope it's at least as fun as this one.
Steeped in important discoveries, yet I never get a clear idea of what these people are up to.
The biggest surprise of Curious George is how it keeps consistently entertaining at a kids' level.
Unfortunately, just when you think Garcon Stupide is going somewhere, Baier screws it up with a melodramatic climax and a political message.
I know it's supposed to be silly, but Slither feels more like a scattershot spoof than a fine-tuned piece of entertainment.
Movies like Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector may be critic-proof, but even die-hard fans of country crude will have to admit that a little Larry goes a long way.
movie_title: Larry the Cable Guy: Health Inspector (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A father takes a spiritual journey from Japan to China to help mend a decades-long rift between himself and his dying son. The lessons learned en route are as profound as they are simple.
movie_title: Riding Alone for Thousands of Miles (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Few films have earned classic status more than Carl Dreyer's 1928 silent study of the 15th-Century teenager who helped lead French troops against the British only to be tried as a heretic.
movie_title: The Passion of Joan of Arc (La Passion de Jeanne d'Arc) (1928)

movie_review_blurb: It's difficult to gauge who gets stranded more in Eight Below: the team of sled dogs left at the bottom of the world or audience members forced to sludge through two hours of very human melodrama to see them reunited with their handler.
A casual interest in dance is all it takes to enjoy Ballets Russes, an enchanting new documentary about the famed French ballet company.
It's not Shakespeare. It isn't even The O.C. But She's the Man still has enough energy to make it slightly better than the usual teen comedy throwaway.
The rerelease of Classe Tous Risques makes you wonder how many other movies this good got scuttled by the French new wave.

The special effects simply thrust Ultraviolet in an Xbox 360 for action set-pieces that are kinetic and colorful but surprisingly unexciting. Do we really care if she dies when she's just going to be regenerated anyway?

Like its title character, Duma has been left to fend for itself by Warner Bros., which is barely releasing it. A successful showing this weekend will prove that there really is an audience for this brand of thoughtful, literate family film.
If the typical IMAX offering has a handful of unforgettable shots, this one delivers about 50.
If there was more content in the Alice Hoffman book on which it is based, the screenwriters keep it effectively submerged.
The Lethal Weapon movies were all about charismatic actors breathing life into stock characters. That doesn't happen with Willis and Def.
Something tells me that the original dialogue, replaced here by references to M.C. Hammer and The Shining, would have added a little to the movie's limited charms.

With its first-person approach, Fateless joins other classic films about the Holocaust (Shoah, Schindler's List) by vividly portraying an event that can seem remote as the number of eyewitnesses shrinks each year.
There have been countless film biographies of famous artists, but only a few can be considered major works in their own right. Place Edvard Munch at the top of the list.
Denver should not get the first and last look at one of the most triumphant performances of Vanessa Redgrave's career. It deserves to be seen everywhere.
Doubt is a missed opportunity, all the way through to its final scene, which isn't nearly the statement it might have been.
Hairspray is an infectious aerosol comedy with nearly every hair in place.
Much more than one of the best movies of the year, Chicago is destined to become the most popular screen adaptation of a stage musical since Grease.

'Die Another Day's' special effects will make your eyes open so wide your contacts might fall out, but the spy caper is double-crossed by a stupid script littered with one-liners so dumb that 007 actually makes XXX (Vin Diesel) sound like he's clever.
An exciting debut from promising, and fairly disturbed, young director/screenwriter Dylan Kidd.
Makhmalbaf's impeccable feature-film debut is a witty and precociously intelligent docudrama.
The quiet, hypnotic intensity of the cinematic journey one experiences in Eternity and a Day is a rare and lasting pleasure.
Draws a consistently witty and heartfelt portrait of contemporary British lives.
A classic tale of gentle anti-authoritarianism.
Played with an unrelenting intensity and lithe grace by Noomi Rapace, Salander is the driving force in this down-and-dirty Swedish language adaptation of Stieg Larsson's international bestseller.
movie_title: The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Similar in tone to Let The Right One In, it starts slowly and builds into a fantastical and creepy look at childhood.

Going by the rushed and open ending, there's potential here for another chapter in June's life, but it's going to have to iron out its kinks if it's to become anything more than an afternoon's distraction.
Lines are read as if unrelated to the ones that came before it, giving conversations a stilted, unnatural coldness.
Despite the charismatic nature of both the leads, Before We Go is a light affair that never really does more than scratch the surface of their characters.

Whilst there's probably not enough story here to warrant the film's admittedly short running time, when it reaches its heightened emotional ending, you have to hand it to screenwriters Patricia Beauchamp and Joe Gossett for trying something different.
Camp and somewhat frothy, Chastity Bites gets by on the strength of its cast who are all clearly having a whale of a time.
It's mean-spirted, vicious and twistedly entertaining, the kind of film that will make you think twice about being left alone and vulnerable in front of your laptop.
The film's strong-minded goal to see these two stay together has enough heart to charm anybody no matter what form they take.
Great to look at, and with an aftertaste that lingers, what you get out of John Doe: Vigilante will depend solely on the way that you swing with this thorny issue.
This is a very by the numbers film that, like its leads, seems to wander aimlessly under the pretence of getting somewhere.
Tiger House is a competent thriller that zips along at a decent pace.

The strength in Nair's bittersweet script comes not from large monologues, but rather the subtle, almost throwaway lines that build up to a surprising yet fitting end that even allows its characters to look out over a sunset without it feeling trite.
It's not a particularly original message, but it's hard to fault a film trying to earnestly spread a little love around the world.
There's nothing overtly flashy about Edgerton's direction, but he crafts some nerve-jolting scares.
A hot-headed bruiser he may have been, but Being Evel concludes that there's no denying he was a true global icon.
The attention to detail is strong and it's hard not to think about De Palma's The Untouchables.
Chloe and Theo is about the difference a Bruce Lee loving westerner has on the life of a mild-mannered, peaceful Inuit. It most certainly should have been the other way round.
Despite its characters living in the woods and being in touch with the elements, The Last Keepers isn't particularly earthy and, at times, comes across as sterile in its delivery.
Sometimes confusing and overwrought when it should be lean and scary, Cell 213 would perhaps fare better as a mini-series.
What it lacks in simplicity of narrative, The Assassin expertly makes up for in its presentation.
Two Men in Town is a dusty, sun bleached saunter through redemption.
Whilst Sinister 2 at least manages to avoid being a mere re-tread, the final product comes off as decidedly flat.
Thrilling in parts but just missing the mark in so many other aspects, Apocalypse literally ends on a confused look instead of a bang.
It's hard to deny the film's ultimate goal of opening up a public discussion about how we wish to be defended by our governments.
Bloodsucking Bastards is as juvenile as its title suggests, but with a strong script and a stronger cast, it's also a lot of irreverent, gore tinged fun.
Doing so much that's been done before, with little room left for anything truly original, Demonic is ultimately a flat experience.

With his British boy band roots firmly behind him, Luke Goss has carved himself quite a career as an action hero and The Night Crew, co-starring Danny Trejo, is perhaps one of the finer examples of his work outside of Hellboy 2.
The film is so serious and portentous that it almost feels languid; as if not really concerned about reaching its end.
Whilst it doesn't stick its landing when the credits roll, Wolf Creek fans are perhaps going to get a kick out of seeing Jarratt failing to get the upper hand for a change.
With outright tenacity, Pump sets its teeth into the problem that establishing an alternative source of fuel is hard when the biggest stakeholders are the ones who would rather it didn't catch on.
Brutal and violent, it becomes obvious in hindsight how much this film needed less replication and a bit more bite.

Director Mel Rodriguez III provides slick visuals and an even slicker soundtrack, but it doesn't hide the fact that the conclusion of In Stereo is that it's really hard when two gorgeous women want you.
When Momentum gets going, there's an entertaining time to be had trying to catch up.
Starting off light and comedic, Aimy in a Cage is a trap that lulls unsuspecting viewers with its Wes Anderson visuals and Roald Dahl storytelling.
This is still a wonderful portrait of a man who chose to embrace life to its fullest whilst biting his thumb at gravity.
At times, it's hilarious, but the tone changes so much that it becomes hard to keep up.
None to subtle in its approach, Zipper works only when it wants to.
A Little Game does feel light enough to be carried away with the next breeze, but it's hard to fault its charm and its young cast.
t's these moments that make Hackney's Finest a lot of fun to watch and for the most part memorable.
White Rabbit ultimately feels exploitative.
Even with Willis - who looks like he was only needed for a day's filming - phoning it in, in every conceivable way, it still manages to be a hell of a lot of fun.
Based on Lindon's own experiences of life inside after a false rape allegation, Rise is a passionate but misguided cry that miscarriages of justice of this kind can happen.
With an emotional punchline and uplifting spirit, The Pa Boys is as laid back and melodic as the tunes the boys peddle on their way to the North Island.
Chilling and tense, The Hunted is certainly worth pursuing.

Miss Meadows is an interesting character study of someone just trying to make the world a better place through murder, and questioning whether her methods may actually be the cause of the world's decay.
Overall, it's a sex positive film that suggests that whether you're swinging from the chandeliers or staying at home in your PJs, what really matters is what you think about yourself.
It's as subtle and as silly as you would expect, with an ending that's both a rally cry and request for a sequel.
Some will balk at the idea of a faith based horror film, however The Remaining successfully manages to walk the fine line between bloody-minded entertainment and religious discourse.

Colin is such a duplicitous example of manhood it's extremely hard to warm to him or his existential crisis. It's certainly not helped by Dornan's lacklustre performance that recalls nothing of what made him so watchable in The Fall.
What We Did On Our Holiday manages to stay afloat because of its completely beguiling charm. It is an absolute joy of a movie.
movie_title: What We Did on Our Holiday (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Quarantine Hauntings is a great example of independent horror being created in Australia that holds enough sting in its tail for those who like endings with a good wallop.
Blue Ruin is a brutal stripped back thriller that suggests more great things to come from Jeremy Saulnier.
Like its antagonist, Exists is a tenacious beast that refuses to let go once it's sunk its teeth in.
As a debut feature, it's a competently put together piece of work that offers up healthy slabs of scares, but it's often in danger of mistaking heightened emotions for character development.
Beyond The Edge brilliantly blends archival footage and reconstructions provide an engrossing, if sometimes dry, retelling of a breathtaking achievement.
Ostensibly an exploration of biblical themes, Left Behind avoids any theological debate to revel unsuccessfully in the mass-hysteria created by God's Rapture.
Writer-director Ajmal Zaheer Ahmad serves up glossy visuals on the back of a limited budget. However, Jinn often feels like it's a showreel for his visual talents. An admittedly uneven one at that.
Unlike its protagonists, Game of Assassins fails to make much progress over the course of its running time.
Trash may not always convince, but is still at all times an engaging drama.
It's easy to get lost in the bloody-mindedness of it all.
