movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: "Good Kill" does not offer any easy moral answers or, for that matter, less-than-intense air-strike sequences that would make it a more painless picture to watch. Of course, the most meaningful ones rarely do.
One of the creepiest disclosures in this rather weird movie comes at the very end, when we discover how a couple of the featured players are getting along now.

For some reason we expected much more from this Farrelly Brothers sequel, whose less-than-energetic screenplay and sparse number of gut-busting laughs makes it one of the year's most disappointing and surprisingly dull films.
Following a few compelling turns and sly plot twists, the final confrontation between gifted student and tyrannical teacher comes quickly, then ends on an equally sudden if just about perfect note.
The good-to-see Rene Russo plays the ratings-happy producer showing off Bloom's wares on a nightly basis, but this is strictly the often chilling Gyllenhaal's one-man show.
Equally remarkable is co-writer and director Innaritu's ability to keep it all whole, constantly coming at us, and innovatively funny.
Tessa Thompson steals the picture with the mostly radical rants of a character described as 'a Lisa Bonet wannabe'.
There are enough light moments -- and even a few surprisingly touching ones -- to recommend it, if only to marvel at how easily the ex-"SNL" star can carry a movie.
There's little syrupy, mindless junk to be found here, just plenty of invention from the 3-D, stop-motion gang that also gave us the step-above "Coraline" and "ParaNorman."

It's not exactly a walk on the wild side, but it will take a stout heart to deal with the hostility and venom dished out by an assortment of troubled parishioners, all introduced taking Holy Communion, of all things.
It truly is an epic account of anyone's/everyone's simple life story.

The twins playing the pre-teen Brown (Jamarion and Jordan Scott) do a sweet job of understating the pain in the childhood of the superstar-to-be, and Boseman carries the rest with a mix of pure talent, confidence, magnetism and rage.

By Friday night, anyone who has seen this first "Guardians" will be speaking volumes about all its future possibilities, especially big-name actors scampering to hop aboard for a potentially huge and long franchise ride.
The best reason to see the film lies in the performance of good ol' Frances Sternhagen...her smoky delivery really is priceless.

Thank goodness Mr. Jang (Min-Sik Choi), the preeminent villain in movies this year, almost saves the day when the story veers toward territory already presented last spring in Johnny Depp's "Transcendence."
Music by six-time Oscar nominee Alexandre Desplat should inspire the senses, too, if somehow the moves of Seigner (the real-life Mrs. Polanski) don't do enough for you.
...a convoluted mix of violence, not-so-witty humor and spaghetti western, with a tad too much tomato sauce thrown on top by director Baltasar Kormakur.
Twenty-three movies into a mostly magnificent directorial career, Clint Eastwood's efficiently minimalist style finally has failed him. Big time.
First love, a friend's powerless deception and a perfectly timeless score, credited to Ryan Miller, keep things moving along in a feel-good kind of way.
Even at a disturbing 168 minutes, the big, bold, bloody "Gangs" and its eloquently quiet ending likely will leave audiences with more goosebumps than scars.

The gorgeously elaborate continuation of "The Lord of the Rings" trilogy is so huge that a column of words cannot adequately describe co-writer/director Peter Jackson's expanded vision of J.R.R. Tolkien's Middle-earth.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: The best film of 2002 comes right out of the '50s...a rich and radiant re-creation of the bittersweet tales told by the long-ago likes of director Douglas Sirk and (Cleveland's own) producer Ross Hunter.
Neal Purvis and Robert Wade mix a relevant story with clever tributes to franchise films. Their robust throwback obviously ensures Bond will survive on screen way beyond "Another Day."
Though death robbed Krzysztof Kieslowski of the opportunity, substantial contributions from the visually adept Tykwer allowed him to leave us a little slice of "Heaven."
Who knows? Perhaps playing the master of his bedroom on so many creepy videotapes did somehow fulfill Crane's urges for more legitimate stardom.
Funny and, at times, poignant, the film from director George Hickenlooper all takes place in Pasadena, "a city where people still read."
Em's lowdown, dirty diatribe may sound like treason, but you might discover that his rhyme is the reason.
Such master screenwriting comes courtesy of John Pogue, the Yale grad who previously gave us "The Skulls" and last year's "Rollerball." Enough said, except: Film overboard!
... the former "SNL" star really is ideal as Anderson's put-upon hero. Regardless, a much longer "stretch" might have been realized with a more mainstream actor in such a whacked-out role.
... an otherwise intense, twist-and-turn thriller that certainly shouldn't hurt talented young Gaghan's resume.
... newcomer Lohman really is the one shining brightest through all the soap suds sprayed by "White Oleander."
Good grief requires consistently great writing. "Moonlight Mile" falls too many yards short.
While locals will get a kick out of spotting Cleveland sites, the rest of the world will enjoy a fast-paced comedy with quirks that might make the award-winning Coen brothers envious.
... the dark, sarcastic tale no doubt will recall the profound likes of "Midnight Cowboy" and "The Graduate" ... That's not such bad company to keep for a boy named Igby and guy named Burr.
... legitimate thrills and chills with minimal bloodshed and only suggested violence.
Sadly, any hoped-for chemistry rarely materializes in a landslide of mostly mean-spirited humor.
My, what a delicately orchestrated film!
... There are enough tacky product placements to open a convenience store.
The message becomes the savior for "The Country Bears," an equal parts silly and sweet tale that wears its great big ol' heart on its grizzly-sized sleeve.
Very special effects, brilliantly bold colors and heightened reality can't hide the giant Achilles' heel in "Stuart Little 2": There's just no story, folks.
... it's the lyrical filmmaking - visually, musically and metaphorically - that will be recalled when all is said and done, perhaps as early as awards time.
... step right up to "The Mothman Prophecies," a veritable director's showcase for energetic young Mark Pellington ("Arlington Road") and his flair for imaginative, brooding camera artistry.

Extra-terrestrials conquer the movie if not planet Earth in "Men in Black II," a film that proves how special effects and makeup master Rick Baker can overcome a lot of ills, particularly the lack of basic plot.

If "Lilo & Stitch" isn't the most edgy piece of Disney animation to hit the silver screen, then this first film to use a watercolor background since "Dumbo" certainly ranks as the most original in years.
Time literally stops on a dime in the tries-so-hard-to-be-cool "Clockstoppers," but that doesn't mean it still won't feel like the longest 90 minutes of your movie-going life.

Singer/composer Bryan Adams contributes a slew of songs - a few potential hits, a few more simply intrusive to the story - but the whole package certainly captures the intended, er, spirit of the piece.

They don't make action-adventure movies better than the often spectacular "Spider-Man," the most exciting film re-creation of a superhero since Christopher Reeve donned a red cape and blue tights in "Superman."

Despite the curlicues of plot, Australian Director John Hillcoat, who always manages to keep us darkly entertained (think about his "Lawless." "The Road," and "The Proposition"), really never loses control. Even his pile-it-on ending somehow seems tidy.
Ren√©e Zellweger, Catherine Zeta-Jones, Richard Gere, Queen Latifah and even sad-faced ol' John C. Reilly will have you singin' and dancin' in the aisles.
"Catch Me" feels capable of charming the masses with star power, a pop-induced score and sentimental moments that have become a Spielberg trademark.
... an often funny, generally poignant and mostly realistic portrait of a common Joe, trying to come to terms with the holes left after a lifetime of hard work.
It doesn't quite deserve the gong, but there are more fascinating acts than "Confessions of a Dangerous Mind."
Poor production values, shoddy editing and too many clich√©s cool off a seen-it-all before comedy that even Sandra Bullock and Melissa McCarthy can't save.
It's certainly not your ol' man's "Lone Ranger," Kemo Sabe, but there's still plenty of kicks and stunts to make you wanna shout, "Hi-O, Silver! Away!"
All of these special ladies -- most of them ironically unsung and often exploited -- obviously know their way around a microphone
If it sounds kinda fun, please know it is, with those aforementioned scientists (TV faces Charlie Day and Burn Gorman) creating some laughs with their goofy nature of oneupsmanship.

In winning an Oscar for their adapted screenplay of "The Descendants," ex-Groundlings comics Faxon and Rash proved they can turn a poignant phrase and still produce enough humor to save the day. They certainly turn the same trick here...

None of it is particularly bloody or violent, but young Wan and twin screenwriters Chad and Carey Hayes, up to now mostly unheralded in the horror genre, fashion a harrowing montage of thrills from beginning to end.

...the outtake that closes the proceedings, with the four principals of the titled "family" applauding and laughing at and with their certified star, Jennifer Aniston, once and always from TV's "Friends," might be the most memorable moment in their movie.
...talk about Matt to the Max! . . . that would be an ultra-stern Matt Damon, whose futuristic tough guy is a legitimate piece of work.
O'Donnell's character isn't the only relative that we and Fischer's Laura come to resent (although she at least finds opportunities to sneak away for cigarette and beer breaks).

...as the ads suggest, it really does all end here for both the genuine and stimulatingly fictitious kids who have grown up dealing with the fulfilling assortment of thrills... horrors, action and laughs so easily generated in the "Potter" movies,
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps the summer's biggest surprise is "Crazy, Stupid, Love." It fills the bill as funny, romantic and simply overflowing with various revelations of its own.
After becoming buddies and deciding to have a fling with "no strings attached" (and this is a much better film than that similarly themed early-year romp), the sex becomes frequent and never boring.

Truth be told, even I found myself laughing more than anticipated at some movie references ("Brokeback Mountain," "Midnight Cowboy" and "The Seven-Year Itch," among them), as well as the inspired silliness of Hank Azaria...
First-timer Jessy Terrero's wing-and-a-prayer direction blows out an engine before the halfway mark of his 90-minute "Airplane!" take-off.
...in a very funny bit of salesmanship (what else?), our heroes talk their way into trying out for the gig, and the rest becomes a cornball and, at times, charming piece of fluff.
Aptly named "Minute" moves easily enough (despite) a silly, shallow screenplay laden with so much more absurdity than any screwball comedy should tolerate.
...a surprisingly topical sequel that warmly embraces universal themes and values under its veil of comedy.
... Oscar voters should reward Sheridan (and his co-writing daughters Naomi and Kirsten) with nominations for picture, director and original screenplay.
Even Curtis's few missteps make relative sense in his otherwise smart and bulging valentine to the world... in an inspired movie with just so much to love, actually.
...a nice little film about a reclusive little man.
It all makes for an interesting look at infamy in the hands of the brash young Cox.
Blanchett turns in her most accessible performance to date by breathing life into Guerin
Director Clint Eastwood has mined more Oscar gold with his most profound work since 'Unforgiven.'

The original "Tomb Raider" was dreadfully dull and still took in almost $300 million at the worldwide box office. Not to worry this time. Oscar winner Angelina Jolie returns to the lead role in all her acrobatic, stunt-filled glory.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: See it to believe it, even if you won't really know whose truth to believe.
... sorry, Charlie, this crowded "Angels" episode plays more slick than shrewd.
... with Father's Day just a few weeks away...'Nemo' swims off with hearts of all ages.
... no "Identity" crisis here. It's just a top-notch thriller fresh enough to become a mini-classic.
. . . Kasdan and co-writer William Goldman lose their grip on oh-so-many things King.
Beresford nicely mixes in as much humor as pathos to take us on his sentimental journey of the heart. It really is a shame that more won't get an opportunity to embrace small, sweet 'Evelyn.'
... (the) big, fat fun is anything but a drag.
Maybe best of all, Hood manages to tell his suspenseful tale in a quick-moving 102 minutes. Other, more long-winded filmmakers should take notice.

Ronan certainly does drive it into solid holiday material for the big screen, but there's also much to cherish about its look, feel and meaningful contributions from just about everyone else involved.

Director Jon Favreau fills it with so many memorable moments that Bill Murray/Baloo's terrific warbling of "The Bare Necessities" almost becomes a footnote in a movie simply swarming with pitch-perfect and major celebrity voices.
. . . a big, bleak, bold, bad-ass beauty of an adventure.

We're talking at least 11, 12, 13, maybe 14 players involved in robbing the Charlotte Motor Speedway. (Not that the Rube Goldbergian plot -- with the accent on rube, of course -- bears any resemblance to any of Soderbergh's trio of "Ocean's" movies).
Renner, particularly, is terrific as a man who knows his job -- and the vast territory -- inside and out, but remains reluctant to get too involved due to some deep-seated family history of his own.
The movie-making segments quickly become reminiscent of "Be Kind Rewind" while managing to entertain more than Michael Gondry's ambitious 2008 dud actually did.
Delicate laughs ensue ... with some meaningful moments of emotion popping up as needed in this unusually framed, slice-of-life tale.
Certainly Lipitz herself goes deep into a first-time filmmaker's bag of tricks and somehow takes all the right steps, too.

Credit should go to director David F. Sandberg ("Lights Out"), whose use of ancient horror staples such as dumb waiters, scarecrows and brave little girls carries an average piece of cinema a long way.
How the titular ghost reveals its timelessly intriguing "story" is a little weird to be sure. Still, even if you don't believe in ghosts, just see it to consider how really haunting life can be.
Land, sea and air, all disturbed by war and freckled with humanity, merge splendidly in another near-masterpiece from writer/director Christopher Nolan.

It plays like a very long TV show and might even remind old-timers of the '50s-era "Adventures of Superman." That's the laughable series in which no one ever recognized George Reeves after he showed up as Clark Kent as soon as his alter ego flew away.
'The Big Sick,' a sweet little romantic comedy, might ease what ails you from other recent movie-going experiences.
If you fancy lots of rock 'n' roll choices in your movies, the latest from Brit Edgar Wright seriously steps on the classical gas.

The strength of 'Beatriz' relies more on the performances of Salma Hayek (as the sad and almost saintly title character) and the always-great John Lithgow (as the rather simply named Doug Strutt) than its obvious screenplay.
Grand acting carries "The Exception" through some nifty little World War II thrills from British director David Leveaux.
Its biggest problem becomes a total lack of common sense, even in the hands of director Colin Trevorrow.
It's certainly no surprise that "I, Daniel Blake" won the Palme d'or at the 2016 Cannes Film Festival. Only a cretin wouldn't fall for such legitimate humanity.
The period drama is so filled with ambiguity that, it says here, you'll be dying to discuss whether its titular beauty is a conniving wench or simply an independent woman.
A never-ending return to the States makes it all seem like just a good TV movie, with a cast that includes Edie Falco and Bradley Whitford, as Megan's divorced parents.
It quickly becomes a so-so horror thriller that takes us deep into the woods and some other dark places.

When the fan sprays potty jokes all over the wall, everyone likely will laugh at something. In our family. the 3-year-old giggled whenever she heard the surname of the villainous Prof. Poopypants (and wait'll you get a load of his full name)!
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Here, in her own surroundings -- and playing with contrivances that include the character's magic bracelets and Lasso of Truth -- Gadot truly appears to be a legitimate movie wonder.
Make no mistake, Debra Winger is the best thing about writer/director Azazel Jacobs' small, back-and-forth story of infidelity in a longtime marriage.
Except for a few death-defying special effects, it's two-plus hours of yo-ho-ho and a bottle of dumb.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Cedar simply makes "Norman" a modest gem from start to finish, including one marvelous scene that gives Gere's wide-eyed title character his brief place in the sun. It just might be the movie moment of the year.
movie_title: Norman (Norman: The Moderate Rise and Tragic Fall of a New York Fixer) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The former New Jersey butcher-turned liquor salesman had a story to tell, and Falardeau has no problem putting it up on screen, warts and all.
This incarnation certainly isn't a bad film; it's simply an annoying one because it's so full of itself.
I'm sure you'll play it all again, Marvel. Next time, though, please give your mostly charismatic creatures a little room to breathe.
The title event literally kicks in with a smart visual flair, and students, teachers and administrators all scramble to save themselves in best "Poseidon Adventure" fashion.
movie_title: My Entire High School Sinking Into the Sea (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It slows down remarkably whenever Isaac's married med student or Bale's crusading journalist start going ga-ga over an Armenian beauty played by Charlotte Le Bon.
Youngsters named Moonee (the divine Brooklynn Prince), Scooty and Jancey become those mischievous and usually unsupervised little rascals all over again.
As played by the superb Andrew Garfield, Robin manages to keep the chip-chip-and-cheerio outlook that almost brightens the film as much as the celebrated Ralph Richardson's glamorous cinematography.
The beauty is in the process, of course, which mixes the art of melancholy Vincent van Gogh with a mystery yarn about his death that becomes compelling in spite of some sentimental goings-on.
This is one of those few allegedly factual sagas that possibly leaves a lump or three in your throat.
Off-and-on Melissa McCarthy goes rude, crude and very lewd as an infinitely unlikable ex-orphan whose huge corporate success turns to failure and back again.
It's always grand to hear Crosby, Stills and Nash in any movie, and their "Helplessly Hoping" here brings a meaningful and calming beauty to it all.
It actually opened nationwide on Valentine's Day, and pity the poor fool who might have taken a first date to such a psychosexual doozy.
The bravura performance of Annette Bening, as late, great femme fatale Gloria Grahame, is the main reason to see it.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's big, bold and brazenly political, in a way that will make viewers think instead of simply shrug their shoulders and wait for the next action-packed set piece.
Even if real fanboys are not pleased with some of the revelations (and, perhaps, not all should be believed), the major impact of The Force will go a long way in keeping everyone relatively happy.

Guillermo del Toro has given us a movie lover's dream in a romantic fantasy/thriller that finds a mute cleaning woman (the brilliant Sally Hawkins) becoming infatuated with the mysterious subject of a top-secret (and mean-spirited) experiment.
Cena does an OK job in relating the warmth of the titled beast, which would rather smell flowers than pick suicidal fights with matadors (an occupation that gets some deserved comeuppance here).

The City of Angels stays more interesting throughout than a couple of other characters do, including a wishy-washy, hotshot lawyer (Colin Farrell) and a rights activist (Carmen Ejogo), popping in and out again as a possible love interest for Denzel.
Kids under about 7 or 8, not to mention squeamish parents, might be freaked out by a few things rarely discussed or seen in animated films.
...another strong effort from the Irish McDonagh, who simply gets it when it comes to grand filmmaking.
Some fine moments of relevancy do shine through, but 'Last Flag' ultimately flies through too many hoops in its search to find what legitimate patriotism is all about.
First-time writer/director Maggie Betts mostly manages to involve viewers in exploring why young ladies actually might want to take the spiritual plunge.
Tremblay, the boy from 2015's extraordinary 'Room,' is pretty special behind the prosthetics that really aren't as hard to look at as a politically correct screenplay might suggest.

There's good reason why this one became a bona fide hit at Toronto's's aptly named "Midnight Madness" program. It's a wild-and-crazy shoot 'em up, not only with some obvious nods to the Western genre, but also a tip of the hat to Quentin Tarantino.
With 'Justice' clocking in at just under two hours, it becomes the shortest offering ever in DC's cinematic universe. That alone scores major points in this little corner of the planet.
It produces a rare match made for mother/daughter movie heaven, and Gerwig and her gifted girls just about get us there.
A Carter Burwell score nicely wraps around this slowly charming telling.
Many of the dazzling images look exactly like a well-preserved old Technicolor film, and the chimps steal the show.
Awards recognition likely won't be repeated on this Agatha Christie-inspired "Express," but it remains a generally swell and lavish-looking ride.

The tone and settings are reminiscent of such watchable '80s clunkers as "Flash Gordon" and "Metalstorm: The Destruction of Jared-Syn," with a little bit of Disney's more recent "Maleficent" thrown in, too.
Somehow, much of it makes for realistically poignant, political drama.
The trigger performance presented by young Barry Keoghan is one of the year's most fascinating . . . in a movie helmed by a master filmmaker.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Though their trip to the altar becomes a crowded and winning one, there are some intimate details which might have been better left unsaid.
Some nice visual perspective from (a sightless) point of view. Lots of pretentious BS, too.

Christopher/Tilston never stops smiling, mostly thanks to his time with a spectacularly wonderful nanny (warmly played by Macdonald) and a few nice chats and charming afternoons in the country woods with his work-oriented father.
Visit "Suburbicon" at your own risk.
The film also presents a group of courageously supportive women (who) provide some powerful moments in this rather persuasive telling.
'Mark Felt' certainly is not an awful movie. It simply has a feel of 'been there, done that.'
movie_title: Mark Felt: The Man Who Brought Down the White House (2017)

movie_review_blurb: None of it is supposed to be funny, despite leading-man Fassbender's character name, Harry Hole, and an ending that actually leaves room for a sequel. Ha!
This is one movie that still will have you thinking about it long after the final credits roll.
Let's just say that girl power is not lacking, as it usually is in these Peyo-inspired stories.
Woody Allen comes up with a very special movie about every six or seven years. Unfortunately, "Wonder Wheel" is not one of them.
This book-based prattle becomes an eye-rolling assortment of kid antics and butt-related sight gags (in fact, maybe a world's record worth of them).
Those once-ugly dolls turn into some beautifully upbeat characters in this delightfully colorful animated take on bliss.
Just when everyone felt comic-book movies have reached critical mass comes, perhaps, the year's finest tentpole movie.

Jenkins' ensemble might be the year's finest, with Naomie Harris, as the boy's crack-addicted mother, and likely winner Mahershala Ali, as a kindly drug dealer, of all things, surely to earn Best Supporting Actress and Actor noms, respectively.
Ewan McGregor chooses an adaptation of Philip Roth's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel for his first directing gig, and it's not a total disaster, especially considering the scale of the book.
Hailee Steinfeld turns in a legitimate star-making performance as the lonely, awkward teen whose world genuinely explodes when her popular brother starts dating her best (read: only) friend.
Miles Teller looks nothing like a boxer (or Pazienza for that matter), but Aaron Eckhart, as famous trainer Kevin Rooney, offers a swell performance during a companion redemption plot.
This whimsical adventure more than delivers on what the title promises.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Simply think "Rain Man" mixed up (and that's certainly the correct term) with a lot of guns and no time to watch Judge Wapner.
Kids just wanna have (all kinds of) fun, and director Andrea Arnold proves it in this long (2:38) road trip for a wild and raunchy bunch of so-called magazine sellers.

Can anyone genuinely relate to any of the three pivotally wacky women or trio of squirrelly men in this alleged "thriller"? The best-selling novel on which it's based just has to be more compelling, doesn't it?
It remains a spiritual, violent and significant telling of preacher Nat Turner's Virginia-based slave rebellion.
'Sully' is a nice little film about a hugely remarkable achievement.
Much about this shaky sports bio seems a little off, including laughable minor caricatures for promoter Don King and legendary sportscaster Howard Cosell.
'Don't Breathe' might be the creepiest movie of the year, and that's saying something after the very good "Green Room" and "The Conjuring 2" both spooked us out earlier.
"The (new) Jungle Book" it's certainly not, but anyone with a heart should enjoy "Pete's" easy-going resolution.

History buffs obviously will appreciate the heft and thought behind "Anthropoid," which is the code name of the murder plot, but the startling gunfight during its climax becomes the stuff of unyielding action movies, too.
Despite a few pokes at the folks from Pixar, nobody will lose any sleep over it. Obviously, these R-rated cinematic tricks from Rogen, et al. are not for kids.

This true story, as directed by the usually reliable Stephen Frears ("The Queen," "Philomena") with period flair showing up once again throughout, simply uh, well . . . never quite hits the proper notes.
In a movie summer of disappointments, 'Suicide Squad' might be the major downer of them all.
Who knew that Tarzan and Jane once again could become the screen duo of the year?
It's a very cute film that little ones especially will adore.
Creepy, skin-crawling "The Conjuring 2" proves a worthy, if little less chilling successor to the original, which this corner deemed its favorite film of 2013.
Awards-worthy special effects and a trio of world-class actors (Jennifer Lawrence, James McAvoy and Michael Fassbender) help place "X-Men: Apocalypse" a few thrills above others of its ilk.

Director and co-writer Shane Black (the grand "Kiss Kiss Bang Bang") offers up '70s-era laughs by the guffaw-full, including one great bit in which Gosling borrows heavily from the very late and ever-great Lou Costello.
There remains a lot to like about it, such as an opening battle offering some sparkling 3-D effects, the thrilling final showdown, and its showcase cast.
The gifted Cheadle and music of the legendary Davis do most of the heavy lifting here, but there's a mesmerizing tempo to it all that takes us through the strange and free-wheeling tale as well.
It's the likable cast that will bring constant smiles to the faces of anyone who remembers the freedoms of being young and enjoying them unabashedly.
Arkin, Caine and Freeman get along so famously and seamlessly that we almost don't notice a remarkably solid supporting cast.
Their 1970 meeting supposes some funny conversation, with Spacey doing a grand impersonation of our 37th President, and Shannon nicely personifying the many eccentricities of "The King."

It's an uncommonly bloody -- and still somehow sensitive -- telling, with the terrific Andrew Garfield, as the aw-shucks hero, mostly mixing and matching with a host of grand actors from Gibson's homeland.
Under the guidance of equally exceptional director/co-writer Denis Villeneuve ("Sicario," "Incendies") this scientific thriller becomes smart, touching and, obviously, one of the year's best films.
Absurdity probably makes "Money Monster" a more entertaining film than it should be . . .
Believe it or not, vomit, urine and two attempted suicides show up in the first three minutes alone of this "holiday comedy" sequel. Even crazier, so do three Academy Award winners.

Keith Maitland's use of real footage and animated characters, who turn into the real survivors of a troubled ex-Marine's barrage from the top of a University of Texas landmark, is as riveting as it gets.

Certainly, the film's futuristic production design is a welcome and constant marvel. However, just another story of robotics melding with humans grows old quickly amidst constant ass-kicking and gloom-and-doom dialogue.

Remember how you felt observing the early moments of "The Hurt Locker," itself a bomb-detonating masterpiece (and 2008 Oscar-winner)? This one raises the melodramatic bar even higher. Can you really stand to watch?
It smells like an "Alien" clone, then seriously does take on, uh, well . . . a somewhat firm life of its own.
Oyetolo ("Selma") and Pike ("Gone Girl") are simply heartbreaking, either together or apart, in turning back family biases and political racism.
Jackman's solemn performance matches perfectly with the surprises Mangold has in store during the emotional and action-packed farewell to an iconic hero.
You really shouldn't be looking at your watch more times than you laugh during an 87-minute comedy.

Though Dudok de Wit's film is a nominee for Best Animated Feature, it says here it won't win ... Regardless, there are more taxing ways to spend 80 minutes than leisurely absorbing his gorgeously framed, often moving images.
Want to put a little gore on your funny bone at the movies this weekend? Then just try to get in to "Get Out," a very clever horror film with enough social satire to start a great debate or three.
This spin-off of 2014's original and, it says here, superior "Lego Movie," features first-film scene-stealer Batman as the centerpiece for about a million and one things swirling around him.
Certainly someone somewhere probably anticipated a notable performance from the regularly distinguished Robert De Niro, as aging Jackie Burke, a mean-spirited standup comic with heart to match.

Through it all, and certainly with their writer/director's guidance, Suarez and the equally marvelous Adriana Jugarte (as the younger Julieta) suggest leading ladies that even the great Hitchcock would embrace.
At times, the whole thing smells of period psychobabble, but it's more often a compelling coming-of-age tale with accomplished cast to match.
If you like the milk shakes at Mickey D's, stay away from this film or you may never enjoy one again. What a Kroc!
'Kong' remains a pretty darn good popcorn movie. Just don't let any of the often gory details thrown up by this alleged "PG-13" offering get in the way of your digestive system.

Not half bad as a rental.
They could've cut 10 minutes out of the first hour easily...and it still might have been too slow.
Well...you could waste a few hours of your life. Does that answer the question?
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Wildly mediocre.
It's good, great in spurts, but overall leaves one longing for a story better suited for film.
The film might as well be entitled Retarded America, but lumping these idiots in with our mentally challenged population would be an insult.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: If you remove all the horror aspects of it, it works nicely as a tourism campaign for Brazil. Never has there been a dumber group of travelers; wait to rent it.
Djimon Hounsou is excellent and Kagiso Kuypers delivers an amazing breakout performance.
An amazing team of talent both in front of and behind the camera stretch a short story into a romantic fairy tale for adults that works.
He can't keep his mouth shut when he has too much tequila, but dammit, this man can tell a story on film.
Technically amazing, but not engaging enough to recommend as theater viewing unless you're an arthouse freak.
Stallone doesn't embarrass himself nor his fans...it's pretty good.
Outstanding work from a young ensemble. Ben Foster steals the show in an over the top performance as an a**kicking, always-in-trouble, speedfreak.
The bar had been raised so high by the first 2 films that reaching it again proves difficult...and they came close. Check it out!
Bruce Willis is still a bada** and this series might not be dead yet...I'm just sayin'.
Fun, but a bit too serious.
That'll do Indy, that'll do.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not the best in the McKay/Apatow canon, but still...it's funny.
Everything you've heard is true...brilliant.
Worth viewing if only to see Clooney, McDormand, and Pitt all play what Malkovich's character refers to as a 'league of morons'.
Definitely a 'summer blockbuster' and has enough great moments in it to outweigh any groaners that it may also have. In fact, the good moments outweigh the bad about 20 to 1.
See it with someone you love...or at least someone who enjoys Sandler.
Remember the people that the Borat film made fun of? They're in this film too, picketing outside of Dixie Chick shows...idiots.
movie_title: Dixie Chicks - Shut Up and Sing (2006)

movie_review_blurb: This movie's great! This movie's great! Hurry, tell everyone that it's great! Why are you looking at me like I'm crazy? It really is great!
The writing is genius, the performances wonderful, and the film as a whole is a complete success.
Not the conspiracy theory rant one would expect from Stone, not at all. It's not a great film, but a good one that was made with love.
The question on everyone's mind is 'Does she look good at age 48?' Oh yeah...make no mistake, she does.
It's hilarious, gross, and insanely watchable! What would a Troma film look like if they had a decent script and a big budget? Like Slither!
Better than the original! Scrat the saber-toothed squirrel once again steals the film...love that squirrel!
Assumes that you know film noir and then that you won't mind high-schoolers trampling one of your favorite genres. An admirable attempt that falls short in the end.
Bottom line, this is thoroughly entertaining. This is the best role of Hartnett's career and he doesn't disappoint.
The Weitz brothers are a 2-headed John Hughes for post-2000 audiences...not always critically aclaimed, but almost always loved by the public. Once again, they succeed.
Good luck having a 'nice day' after leaving this film. You'll be an emotional wreck in need of a hug.
A Karate Kid-esque story of a intelligent girl that battles against the pressure to 'keep it real'...and wins.
Is that Simon Pegg from Shaun of the Dead? Yeah, it is!
If a ship flips over and it's full of people that nobody cares about, does it matter if anyone makes it out alive? Allow me to answer that rhetorical question...no.
Would've worked better as a made-for-TV mini-series.
Not as cool as the first two, but worth a look just to see Vinnie Jones as Juggernaut run through things.
If it could've been a little more stupid, it would've been bad-good. It's worth a look for those who love bad cinema.
This is a very watchable film...not your standard rom-com garbage.
Altman's direction and Keillor's writing mesh perfectly in this quirky, yet 'homey and welcoming' film.
Has one of the best on-screen deaths ever put on film...truly grotesque and effective.
The plot is a mish-mash of several Saturday morning cartoon plots and/or bad movie plots.
movie_title: Garfield: A Tail of Two Kitties (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Try to ignore the parallels Singer draws between Christ and Superman...go ahead, I dare ya.
More fun than the cantina scene from Star Wars, Davy Jones and his barnacle-encrusted crew alone make this a must see!
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Man's Chest (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Kate Hudson looks great in a swimsuit and heels...is that enough to recommend theater viewing? Not really.
It's a great looking film and the destination is worthy, but the journey leaves you wanting something more.
The best film I've ever seen with a full grown man masquerading as a baby...hmmm.
It's an ambitious mess at best, and the invented mythology is delivered to the viewer with the subtlety of a sledgehammer.
Uma is sexy, Luke is funny, and the script is hilarious...check it out!
Made for teenagers and they'll be seeing it no matter what we say. I would too if I was 16 and saw the poster. Wait for the DVD.
Pray to Tom Cruise and Oprah Winfrey that Ferrell keeps making silly movies like this.
movie_title: Talladega Nights: The Ballad of Ricky Bobby (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Pixar is truly the Ferrari of animation studios...another winner!
Incredibly average...wait for cable.
Although it's well made and entertaining enough to recommend, the actual point of the film is...well, hard to find.
The cinematic equivalent of really slow, beyond deliberate, wish-it-was-over-with-already kick to the groin. Would've been stellar as a short though...seriously!
Although I liked/respected it in on some level, for sheer entertainment value it's lacking. Wait to rent it.
...Knightly is done a major disservice by the costumer. Some may think her fighting garb is sexy, others will agree with me that it makes her look like a 12 year old boy.
Robots, explosions, gunplay, action, Will Smith...hmmm, it must be July.
Matt Damon...yeah, he's still a badass.
A monumental disappointment. I love Shyamalan's films but this one is only cable worthy.

Beautiful!

A painful watch for those not into video games or 'zombie action', but will please fans of the first film and the rabid gamer.

It's incredibly retro while being fantastically futuristic. The world that Kerry Conran has created is fantastic, surreal, and completely engrossing.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Visually stunning and mentally numbing. Not only will you not be able to understand it...you won't care.
Cool effects and a great central concept do not a good film make. A decent one? Yes, but wait to rent it.
Never has the 'silent-but-deadly' [or SBD] been used with such care.
This film is a marketing vehicle that reeks of focus groups and the involvement of the 'suits'.
...there's no good reason to go see this movie, but you probably knew that already.
An accurate potrayal of Texas High School football and the overzealous participation of those not even on the team. Great stuff!
Whether you're able to grasp how they do it is unimportant [you won't], but being intrigued by the idea is what will rope you in to this one.
When your main character goes off into a fantasy world where anything can happen and absolutely nothing does, that's unfortunate.
This film is all about mood and atmosphere...not very accessible or intriguing.
Wonder what Matt Damon did to piss these guys off?
It's disturbing, funny, uncomfortable, heartbreaking, and absolutely facsinating.
Great ads/trailer, lame movie.

Proof that the human story of a superhero can be told and not be boring...ahem...Hulk anyone?

Every bit as good as the original, but that's not saying much.
...will probably be good for the kiddos who see that there's a 'horsey' movie playing at the cineplex, but for any adults wanting a sweeping epic, look elsewhere.

Zzzzzzzzzzz, [drool] zzzzzzzz.

Better than the original, faster and funnier than 28 Days Later, and just plain entertaining. This flick kicks zombie a**!

movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's made for kids and they will absolutely LOVE this! The monsters are as fun as the ones from the original Ghostbusters!

Plays as if the filmmakers were doing an experiment to see if they could pull one over on the audience, the studio execs, and the actors.

A great continuation of the series and immediately available for viewing in IMAX! See it that way if you can!

movie_review_blurb: Doesn't reach the hilarious heights that its short film predecessor Peluca does. It's funny in places, but not satisfying...wait to rent it.

...although Foxx's performance may go down as one of the best in a biopic ever, I feel as though the film itself will be remembered as good, but not great.
Pixar's track record is Incredible! Yet another great film for kids and adults alike!
...will be the favorite film of the year for many and it's in my top 5.
An absolutely ridiculous movie that happens to be ridiculously fun.
Barely fresh...and then only for 10 year olds and younger.

movie_review_blurb: Is there such a thing as 'art-house gore'? Why yes...there is.
Nolan has outdone both Burton & Schumacher and resurrected the franchise...bless you Christopher Nolan.
Wonderful debut from director Chris Terrio, can't wait to see more from him.
...inspires the same jaw-dropping awe as Jurassic Park and Close Encounters both did with the same mix of fantasy, horror, and the regular guy.

It's fun, it's weird, it's visually stunning. It's what going to the movies to escape is all about.

Pretty darn good until the last 90 seconds...and then it drips with cheese.
Masterfully crafted, wonderfully acted, and an undeniably cutting commentary on fear in the 50s that resonates even louder today.

Will entertain its target audience with ease. A wonderfully pleasing family safe film.
movie_title: Dreamer: Inspired by a True Story (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A solid film that's worth seeing in the theater, but the Oscar buzz is questionable.

Destined to be a favorite...on cable TV.
For those who know of Omar Khayyam, make the trip to the theater to see this one. If you're just curious, wait for the DVD.
movie_title: The Keeper: The Legend of Omar Khayyam (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Russell Crowe is the new Meryl Streep...all he has to do is be in a movie in any given year and he's a lock for an Oscar nod.

Aerosmith's Steven Tyler is an elf? How cool is that!?
Watching this film is like going to a bad history class where the teacher is a poor storyteller.
Fits together almost too perfectly, but you'll be able to forgive that. It's a wonderful film that is absolutely beautiful. Cheers to cinematographer Bruno Delbonnel!
Do you really know that person you live with? Maybe.
Sandler brings a humanity and sweetness to his role that makes one forget the brashness of Happy Gilmore and Mr. Deeds.

...not only has one too many twists, it probably has 2 or 3 too many.

Brilliant! I can't wait to see it again!
Lots of fun for its target audience; skaters both old school and new, and high schoolers.
Get through the first hour and a half and then wait to be creepily enthralled. It's a nice climactic scene and Watts delivers a line that would make Schwarzenegger proud.
It's funny, sweet, touching, and pure movie magic.
Bernie Mac has a natural delivery and can work a punchline like nobody's business.
Wow! $*#@-ing wow!
Did you like the Barbershop movies? You'll like this too.
Why the Godfather of gaming was exiled to the 'extras' on the DVD is a mystery to me. Outside of that, it's a decent flick.
The movie's not that good, but if Rachel Nichols wants to babysit me, I'm ready to be 10 years old again.
Ever wonder where Radiohead got the title 'Paranoid Android'? Meet Marvin the robot... he's a real party.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There is hardly a word that escapes from anyone's mouth that isn't plain moronic. There are loads of big boobs though, both figuratively and literally...good times.
Haggis gets several 'best performances of their careers' from his actors including Sandra Bullock, Matt Dillon, Thandie Newton, Jennifer Esposito, and Terrence Dashon Howard.
While it will soon be forgotten and its central message ignored by those in power, it's a great looking film that's better than recent 'epics'.
Oh my... it's neither spongeworthy nor Vader-riffic.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Much like the inexplicable tornado at the end that causes this film to truly derail...this blows.
...they do what you should as filmmakers, which is to entertain your target audience...sufficient fare for little girls.
Pure greatness.
